plants.name: Helianthus annuus
plants.description: A tall annual plant known for its large, bright yellow flower heads which track the sun throughout the day. Sunflowers are widely cultivated for both ornamental and agricultural uses, and provide nectar and seeds for wildlife.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, native to North America
plants.funFact: Sunflowers exhibit heliotropism, turning their heads to follow the sun for optimal photosynthesis during early growth stages.

plants.name: Rhododendron arboreum
plants.description: An evergreen shrub or small tree producing clusters of vibrant red flowers. It is the national flower of Nepal and found naturally at high altitudes in the Himalayas, flourishing in cool monsoon climates.
plants.location: Himalayan regions of Nepal, India, Bhutan
plants.funFact: Its bright red flowers attract birds and bees, facilitating cross-pollination at high altitudes.

plants.name: Echinacea purpurea
plants.description: A herbaceous perennial native to North America, recognized for its purple-pink petals surrounding a spiky orange central cone. It is popular in gardens and revered for its medicinal properties.
plants.funFact: Echinacea is widely used in herbal remedies believed to boost the immune system.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A hardy Australian tree known for its cylindrical golden flower spikes and distinctive serrated leaves. It blooms in late winter through spring and summer, providing nectar for native birds and insects.
plants.funFact: Banksia flowers are composed of hundreds of tiny individual flowers packed together, creating dense flower spikes.
